question: What is the procedure for the payment of compensation to proprietors and other entitled parties?
answer: The Revenue-officer shall proceed to make payment to the proprietors, tenure-holders, and other rent-receivers, as well as cultivating raiyats and others, who are shown in the Compensation Assessment-roll as finally modified to be entitled to compensation. The payment is to be made after deducting any amounts ordered to be deducted and any recoverable amounts. If there is a dispute over title, the amount is kept in deposit with the Collector.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter X, Section 54
context: The Revenue-officer makes payment of compensation to proprietors and other entitled parties after deducting required amounts and resolving disputes. Reference URL: http://bdlaws.minlaw.bd/act-print-241.html

question: What are the conditions for the presumption of rents settled under this Chapter?

question: What is the procedure for the payment of annuities to the Commissioner of Wakfs?

question: How are arrears of rent treated in terms of interest?

question: What is the procedure for the recovery of advance rent or bid money realized by outgoing rent-receivers?

question: What are the provisions for the recovery of arrears of rent and cesses?

question: How is the fair and equitable rent determined for a new holding or tenancy?

question: What are the limitations on the mortgage of raiyat holdings?
answer: A raiyat shall not enter into any form of usufructuary mortgage other than a complete usufructuary mortgage. The period for such a mortgage shall not exceed seven years, and it must be registered under the Registration Act, 1908. The mortgage can be redeemed at any time before the expiry of the period, with the redemption amount proportional to the unexpired period.

question: What is the procedure for the redemption of a usufructuary mortgage?
answer: If a mortgagee prevents the redemption of a usufructuary mortgage or refuses to restore land after the mortgage period, the mortgagor may apply to the Subdivisional Magistrate or an authorized officer. question: What are the conditions under which the interest of a raiyat in a holding is extinguished?
answer: The interest of a raiyat in a holding is extinguished under the following conditions: (a) when he dies intestate leaving no heir entitled to inherit under the law of inheritance to which he is subject; (b) when he surrenders his holding at the end of any agricultural year by giving notice in the prescribed form and in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed period to the Revenue-officer; (c) when he voluntarily abandons his residence without making any arrangement for payment of the rent as it falls due and ceases to cultivate his holding either by himself or by members of his family or by, or with the aid of, servants or labourers or with the aid of partners or bargadars for a period of three successive years; or (d) when such interest has devolved by inheritance, under the law of inheritance to which such raiyat is subject, on a person who is not a bona fide cultivator and such person has not cultivated the land comprised in the holding either by himself or by members of his family or by, or with the aid of, servants or labourers or with the aid of partners or bargadars during the period of five years from the date on which such interest has so devolved on him and there is no sufficient cause why he has not so cultivated the land.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XIII, Section 92

question: What are the conditions for the establishment of a Land Survey Tribunal?
answer: The Government may establish Land Survey Tribunals by notification in the official Gazette to dispose of suits arising out of the final publication of the last revised record-of-rights prepared under section 144. The Government may also fix and alter the territorial limits of the jurisdiction of any Land Survey Tribunal. The Government shall, in consultation with the Supreme Court, appoint the judge of the Land Survey Tribunal from among persons who are Joint District Judges. Until such a judge is appointed, the Government may empower a Joint District Judge in each district as the judge of the Land Survey Tribunal of the district. The Joint District Judge empowered under this provision shall be deemed to be the judge of the Land Survey Tribunal appointed under the relevant section. The Government may also appoint one or more Senior Assistant judge or Assistant Judge as a judge of the Land Survey Tribunal to dispose of suits transferred by the judge of the Land Survey Tribunal.

question: What is the procedure for the extinguishment of the interest of a raiyat in a holding?
answer: When the interest of a raiyat in a holding is extinguished, the Revenue-officer may enter on the holding, and the holding shall vest absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances except the encumbrances on the holding which is extinguished under clause (a) of the said sub-section. The persons whose interests in the holdings are extinguished under clauses (b), (c), and (d) of that sub-section shall continue to be personally liable for the money secured by the encumbrances on such holdings. Before entering on a holding, the Revenue-officer shall cause a notice to be published in the prescribed manner declaring his intention to so enter on the holding and specifying the reasons thereof and also inviting objections from all persons interested in the holding. The Revenue-officer shall consider any objections that may be submitted to him within the period specified in that behalf in the notice and shall record a decision. Any person aggrieved by an order passed by the Revenue-officer under sub-section (3) on any objection shown against the extinguishment of the interest of any raiyat in his holding under clause (d) of sub-section (1) may, instead of filing an appeal under section 147, institute a suit in the Civil Court against such order. Such a suit shall be filed within ninety days from the date of the order of the Revenue-officer under sub-section (3).

question: Under what circumstances can a land vested in the Government be settled?
answer: Except as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, any land which vests in the Government under any of the provisions of this Act shall be absolutely at the disposal of the Government. The Government shall be competent to make settlement of such land in accordance with such rules as it may make in this behalf or to use or otherwise deal with such land in such manner as it thinks fit. No land shall be settled with a person unless he is a person to whom transfer of land can be made under section 90. In making settlement of any cultivable land, preference shall be given to an applicant for settlement who cultivates land by himself or by the members of his family and holds a quantity of cultivable land which, added to the quantity of cultivable land, if any, held by the other members of his family, is less than three acres.

question: Under what conditions can a tenant's homestead be removed within the landlord's homestead?

question: What are the rules for the payment of rent by tenants?

question: What is the purpose of Section 122 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: Section 122 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 outlines the process for preparing a scheme for the consolidation of holdings when certain conditions are met. The Revenue Officer must prepare a scheme in cases where no agreement is reached, an application is made, or the government directs consolidation. This ensures that land is consolidated in a fair and equitable manner.

question: What happens if no scheme for consolidation is submitted with an application under Section 119?

question: What is the role of the Advisory Committee under Section 122?

question: What happens if an agreed scheme is produced under Section 122(1a)?

question: What is the Revenue Officer required to consider when preparing a consolidation scheme?
answer: The Revenue Officer must consider proposals with the largest measure of agreement among affected parties and ensure that the redistribution of lands minimally affects the total area or profit of a holding. This ensures fairness and minimizes disruption to raiyats.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 122

question: What is the compensation provision under Section 122(4)?
answer: Under Section 122(4), if the redistribution of lands results in a raiyat receiving land of lower market value than their original parcel, the Revenue Officer must provide for compensation to the affected raiyat. This compensation is paid by the raiyats who benefit from the more valuable land.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 122

question: How should the Revenue Officer handle land with varying productivity under Section 122(5)?
answer: Under Section 122(5), the Revenue Officer should give due consideration to the fact that land productivity may vary from year to year. They must attempt to preserve the balanced character of holdings, and if necessary, consolidate holdings in different levels or blocks to maintain productivity.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 122

question: What is the procedure for dealing with encumbrances under Section 122(6)?
answer: Under Section 122(6), the Revenue Officer must ascertain all encumbrances, including mortgages, attached to the land. question: What is the requirement regarding the total rent of holdings under Section 122(7)?

question: How should rent be apportioned if the value of a holding changes under Section 122(8)?
answer: Under Section 122(8), if the value of a holding is materially changed, the Revenue Officer must apportion the rent in such a way that the incidence on the owners bears the same proportion to the value of each holding as it did before. This ensures fairness in rent distribution.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 122

question: What is the requirement for a consolidated holding under Section 122(9)?

question: What is the procedure for appealing an order under Section 124 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: Under Section 124 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, any person aggrieved by an order of the Revenue Officer confirming a scheme under section 121 or sub-section (2) of section 123 may file an appeal with the prescribed superior Revenue Authority within the prescribed period. The decision of this superior authority on the appeal is final, subject to the provisions of sub-section (2).
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 124

question: Who can file an appeal under Section 124 of the Act?
answer: Any person who is aggrieved by an order of the Revenue Officer confirming a scheme under section 121 or sub-section (2) of section 123 can file an appeal under Section 124 of the Act.

question: What happens after the superior Revenue Authority decides on an appeal under Section 124?
answer: The decision of the superior Revenue Authority on an appeal under Section 124 is final, subject to the provisions of sub-section (2) of the same section.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 124

question: Can a second appeal be filed under Section 124?
answer: Yes, a second appeal can be filed under Section 124. If the superior Revenue Authority passes an order on the first appeal, a second appeal can be presented to the Board of Land Administration, provided it is done in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed period.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 124

question: Who is the authority to which the second appeal under Section 124 can be filed?

question: What is the significance of sub-section (2) of Section 124?
answer: Sub-section (2) of Section 124 of the Act allows for a second appeal to the Board of Land Administration from the decision of the superior Revenue Authority on the first appeal. However, this second appeal is subject to the prescribed manner and period of filing.

question: What are the conditions for filing a second appeal under Section 124?
answer: A second appeal under Section 124 can be filed only if it is presented in the prescribed manner and within the period prescribed in the Act. The appeal must be filed against an order passed on the first appeal by the superior Revenue Authority.

question: Can the Board of Land Administration overturn the decision of the superior Revenue Authority?
answer: Yes, the Board of Land Administration can review and overturn the decision of the superior Revenue Authority on an appeal under Section 124, provided the second appeal is filed in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed period.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 124

question: What is the role of the superior Revenue Authority under Section 124?
answer: The superior Revenue Authority under Section 124 of the Act is responsible for hearing the appeal filed by a person aggrieved by an order of the Revenue Officer and making a final decision on the appeal, subject to the provisions of sub-section (2).

question: What is the procedure for filing an appeal under Section 124?

question: Is there a time limit for filing an appeal under Section 124?
answer: Yes, there is a prescribed period within which an appeal under Section 124 must be filed. The time limit is specified in the Act and must be strictly followed.

question: What are the consequences of not filing an appeal within the prescribed period under Section 124?
answer: If an appeal under Section 124 is not filed within the prescribed period, the aggrieved person may lose their right to challenge the order of the Revenue Officer, and the decision may become final and binding.

question: Can the Board of Land Administration be the final authority in appeals under Section 124?
answer: Yes, the Board of Land Administration is the final authority in appeals under Section 124. It can hear a second appeal from the superior Revenue Authority and make a final decision on the matter.

question: What types of orders can be appealed under Section 124?

question: What happens if the superior Revenue Authority dismisses an appeal under Section 124?
answer: If the superior Revenue Authority dismisses an appeal under Section 124, the original order of the Revenue Officer remains in effect, and the aggrieved person may not have any further recourse unless a second appeal is filed with the Board of Land Administration.

question: What is the procedure for the consolidation of holdings under the Act?
answer: The Revenue-officer is responsible for preparing a scheme for consolidation of holdings in cases where no scheme is submitted, where the scheme is not agreed upon, or where the Government orders consolidation. The scheme must consider the interests of raiyats, ensure that the total area or profit of a holding is not adversely affected, and provide for compensation if necessary. The scheme must also preserve the balanced character of holdings and apportion rent according to the value of holdings.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 - Part IV, Chapter XV, Section 122
context: The consolidation of holdings is governed by Section 122 of the Act, which outlines the procedure for preparing a scheme for consolidation, the role of the Revenue-officer, and the considerations that must be taken into account when preparing the scheme.

question: What is the procedure for the preparation of a scheme for consolidation of holdings?
answer: The Revenue-officer must prepare a scheme for consolidation of holdings in specified cases. The scheme should be prepared in accordance with the provisions of the Act and any rules made by the Government. The Revenue-officer may appoint an Advisory Committee to assist in the preparation of the scheme, and the scheme must be dealt with in the same manner as provided in Section 121.

question: What are the considerations for the redistribution of lands during consolidation?
answer: During the redistribution of lands for consolidation, the Revenue-officer must ensure that the total area of a holding or the profit derived from it is affected as little as possible. If the redistribution results in a raiyat receiving land of lower market value than their original parcel, the Revenue-officer must provide for compensation to the raiyat who benefits from the more valuable land.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 - Part IV, Chapter XV, Section 122
context: Section 122 of the Act outlines the considerations for the redistribution of lands during consolidation, including the requirement to compensate raiyats who are adversely affected by the redistribution.

question: What is the procedure for dealing with encumbrances during consolidation?
answer: Before confirming a consolidation scheme, the Revenue-officer must ascertain all encumbrances, including mortgages, attached to the land. A notice must be issued calling upon beneficiaries of encumbrances to declare their interests. If they fail to declare within the fixed period, the encumbrances cease to be attached to the land after consolidation.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 - Part IV, Chapter XV, Section 122
context: Section 122 of the Act specifies the procedure for dealing with encumbrances during consolidation, including the requirement to issue a notice and the consequences of failing to declare encumbrances.

question: What is the procedure for dealing with the rent in a consolidation scheme?
answer: The Revenue-officer must ensure that the sum total of the rent of all holdings under the consolidation scheme is not reduced by the redistribution of lands. If the value of a holding is materially changed, the rent must be apportioned in such a way that the incidence on the owners bears the same proportion to the value of each holding as it did before.

context: Section 122 of the Act outlines the procedure for dealing with rent in a consolidation scheme, ensuring that the redistribution of lands does not reduce the total rent and that the incidence of rent remains proportional to the value of each holding.

question: What is the legal status of land gained by accession from the recess of a river or sea?
answer: Such land vests absolutely in the Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and is at their disposal.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, Part V, Chapter XIII, Section 87
context: Land gained by accession from the recess of a river or sea vests absolutely in the Government of Bangladesh. This applies to all such lands whether gained before or after June 28, 1972, unless the right of a Malik to hold such land was recognized by a competent authority before the commencement of the State Acquisition and Tenancy (Sixth Amendment) Order, 1972.

question: What is the legal effect of the State Acquisition and Tenancy (Sixth Amendment) Order, 1972 on land gained by accession?
answer: The provisions of Section 87 apply to all lands gained by accession whether before or after June 28, 1972, unless the right of a Malik to hold such land was recognized by a competent authority before the commencement of the Order.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, Part V, Chapter XIII, Section 87
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy (Sixth Amendment) Order, 1972 affects the legal status of land gained by accession. If the right of a Malik to hold such land was recognized before the Order, the provisions of Section 87 do not apply.

question: What is the presumption regarding rents settled under Chapter XIV of the Act?

answer: The rent may be reduced on the grounds that (a) the rent is substantially higher than the rent calculated at the rates of rent determined under this Chapter for similar classes of land, (b) the soil of the holding has deteriorated due to natural causes, or (c) there has been a breakdown of existing arrangements for irrigation or drainage leading to soil deterioration.

question: What is the maximum rate of rent for a class of land?
answer: The rate of rent for any class of land shown in a table of rent-rates confirmed under section 101 shall be the maximum rate at which the rent of a raiyat or non-agricultural tenant for such class of land can be settled.

question: How long can the rent settled under this Chapter remain unaltered?
answer: When the rent of a tenant has been settled under this Chapter, it shall not be enhanced for a period of twenty years; and no such rent shall be reduced within the said period save on the ground specified in clause (b) or clause (c) of section 106.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XIV, Section 114
context: The rent settled under this Chapter remains unaltered for twenty years. Reduction is allowed only under specific grounds mentioned in section 106.

question: What is the procedure for preparing a Compensation Assessment-roll?

context: Compensation Assessment-roll can be prepared based on existing record-of-rights, either without revision or with specified revisions, as per Government notification.

question: What happens to arrears of rent and cesses due to a rent-receiver?
answer: All arrears of rent and cesses together with interest thereon, which remained due to any rent-receiver in respect of any interest on the date of acquisition of such interest under the provisions of this Act and which have not been barred by limitation, and all sums due to him in respect of any decree for such arrears whether having the effect of a rent decree or money decree and whether obtained before or after the date of acquisition, the execution of which is not barred by limitation, shall continue to be recoverable by such rent-receiver amicably or through Civil Court from the persons liable to pay them.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IXA, Section 68C
context: Arrears of rent and cesses, along with interest, are recoverable by the rent-receiver through amicable means or Civil Court, provided they are not barred by limitation.

question: What are the consequences of subletting land in khas possession?
answer: On and from the date of publication of a notification under sub-section (3) of section 17 or under sub-section (1) of section 31, no person shall sublet any land in his khas possession in the area to which such notification relates. Any subletting made in contravention of sub-section (1) shall be null and void and the land so sublet shall be forfeited to the Government.

context: Subletting land in khas possession is prohibited after the publication of a notification. Any such subletting is null and void, and the land is forfeited to the Government.

question: What happens to applications, suits, or proceedings under sections 105, 105A, and 106 of the Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885, or sections 121, 122, and 123 of the Sylhet Tenancy Act, 1936, when an order is made under section 31?

question: How is rent exempted for land used as a place of public prayer or religious worship?
answer: A malik or non-agricultural tenant holding land used primarily as a place of public prayer or religious worship, public graveyard, or public cremation ground may apply for rent exemption. The Deputy Commissioner shall examine the application and, if satisfied, determine the area of the land used for such purposes and pass an order exempting that area from rent. If the area is part of a holding or tenancy, it is separated to create a separate rent-free tenancy, and the rent for the original holding is reduced accordingly.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What are the procedures for appealing against a Deputy Commissioner's order on rent exemption?
answer: Any person aggrieved by an order of the Deputy Commissioner under Section 151A(3) may prefer an appeal to the Commissioner of the Division within thirty days. The Commissioner may then refer the matter to the Board of Land Administration for further revision within sixty days of the order.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What is the process for handling disputes regarding the apportionment of compensation?

question: How are pending cases for recovery of arrears of rent transferred upon the coming into force of an ordinance?
answer: All pending cases for recovery of arrears of rent and applications for execution of decrees made by a rent-receiver under Chapter IXA, pending before a Certificate Officer on the date of coming into force of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy (Second Amendment) Ordinance 1957, shall be transferred to the Civil Court which has jurisdiction over the matter. The transferred cases shall be treated as plaints or applications for execution of a decree under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IXA, Section 68B

question: What is the procedure for treating multiple rent-receivers jointly for compensation assessment?
answer: When more than one proprietor, tenure-holder, or other rent-receiver jointly hold rent-receiving interests and the total net income of such interests does not exceed five hundred rupees, such proprietors, tenure-holders, or other rent-receivers may be treated jointly for the purpose of assessment of compensation under this Chapter.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IXA, Section 68A

question: What are the provisions for transitory cases under Chapter IXA?
answer: All requisitions for recovery of arrears of rent and applications for execution of decrees made by a rent-receiver under Chapter IXA for which this Chapter is being substituted and pending before any Certificate Officer on the date of coming into force of the East Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy (Second Amendment) Ordinance 1957 shall be transferred to the Civil Court which has jurisdiction to entertain a suit for the recovery of the arrears of rent to which such requisition or application relates.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IXA, Section 68B

question: What is the time frame for the liability of exempted holdings for re-assessment under section 151F?
answer: If a person who is exempted from payment of land revenue under section 151C acquires agricultural land exceeding twenty-five standard bigahs in total, the entire quantity of agricultural land held by him and his family is liable to land revenue. The liability starts from the first day of Kartik of the Bengali year if the acquisition was before that date, or from the first day of the Bengali year next following the acquisition if it was on or after that date.

question: What is the procedure for admitting an application for consolidation under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?

question: What are the procedures for handling arrears of rent for lands held by tenants under the Government?

question: What is the procedure for correcting the Record-of-Rights?
answer: The Revenue-officer must open a file for mutation of the Record-of-Rights upon receiving notice under section 89. They will issue notice to the co-sharers of the holding for mutation. question: What are the grounds for enhancing rent under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act?
answer: Rent may be enhanced if it is substantially lower than the rent calculated at the rates of rent determined under this Chapter for similar classes of land in the unit in which the land is situated. question: What are the grounds for enhancing the rent of a raiyat or non-agricultural tenant?
answer: The rent payable by a raiyat or non-agricultural tenant may be enhanced if it is substantially lower than the rent calculated at the rates of rent determined under the Chapter for similar classes of land in the unit where the land is situated and entered in the table of rent rates, confirmed under section 101.

The rent may be enhanced if it is substantially lower than the rates determined for similar land in the same unit. Additionally, there are limits to the enhancement, such as not exceeding fifty per centum of the rent payable during the immediately preceding year unless otherwise directed.

question: What are the limitations on the enhancement of rent?
answer: The enhancement of rent is limited such that if the increase exceeds fifty per centum of the rent payable during the immediately preceding year, the enhancement must take effect by yearly increments over a number of years. Additionally, the increase in a particular year shall not exceed fifty per centum of the rent payable during the year immediately preceding the year from which the new assessment takes effect.

question: What are the conditions for reducing the rent of a raiyat or under-raiyat?
answer: The Revenue-officer may reduce the rent payable by a raiyat or under-raiyat if it is considered unfair or inequitable. The reduction for a raiyat may not exceed the fair and equitable rent for similar lands, while for an under-raiyat, the reduction may not exceed the fair and equitable rent for an occupancy raiyat increased by fifty per centum.

question: What is the procedure for commuting the rent of a raiyat or under-raiyat to a money-rent?
answer: The Revenue-officer may commute the rent of a raiyat or under-raiyat to a fair and equitable money-rent, not exceeding one-tenth of the total value of the annual gross produce of the land. question: What is the process for determining fair and equitable rent for raiyats and under-raiyats?
answer: The Revenue-officer shall presume the rent to be fair and equitable. If the rent is considered unfair, the Revenue-officer may reduce it to a fair and equitable amount. For under-raiyats, the rent may be reduced to an amount not exceeding the fair and equitable rent of an occupancy raiyat, increased by fifty per centum. If the rent is paid in kind or at varying rates, it shall be commuted to a fair and equitable money-rent, not exceeding one-tenth of the total value of the annual gross produce, with a margin of profit for the superior landlord.

The Revenue-officer has the authority to reduce rent if it is deemed unfair or inequitable, taking into account local rental rates and the value of the produce.

question: What is the procedure for scaling down debts of rent-receivers under Section 70?
answer: Under Section 71, the Government can authorize a Revenue-officer to scale down the debts of rent-receivers. The Revenue-officer must publish a notice calling upon creditors to submit statements of debts owed to them by the rent-receivers. If a creditor fails to submit the statement within the prescribed period, the liability to pay such debt is extinguished. The Revenue-officer then examines the submitted statements, allows creditors and debtors to present their cases, and makes necessary modifications. Finally, the Revenue-officer scales down the debts in accordance with Section 70 and takes other actions required by that section.

context: The procedure involves notice publication, creditor submission, liability extinguishment, examination of statements, and scaling down of debts. The process includes appeals to a Special Judge under Section 71(6).

answer: Section 143C of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 outlines the procedure for correcting the Record-of-Rights. When a Revenue Officer receives a notice under Section 89, they must open a file for mutation of the Record-of-Rights and issue a notice to the co-sharers of the holding. If no objection is raised within the stipulated period, the Revenue Officer can correct the record accordingly. question: What are the rules regarding the payment of rent by a raiyat?
answer: The rent payable by a raiyat shall be paid in two equal instalments falling due on such dates as may be prescribed. However, if there is an agreement or establishment usage, this may vary.

question: What are the rules regarding the payment of rent by a non-agricultural tenant?

question: What are the rules regarding the preparation of record-of-rights?
answer: After an order has been made under section 17 directing the preparation or revision of a record-of-rights in respect of any area, no Civil Court shall entertain any suit or application for the alteration of rent or determination of the status of any tenant or the incidents of any holding or tenancy in such area. If any such suit or application relating to such area is pending before a Civil Court on the date of such order, it shall not be further proceeded with and shall abate.

question: What are the rules regarding the limitation on mortgage of raiyat holdings?
answer: A raiyat shall not enter into any form of usufructuary mortgage other than a complete usufructuary mortgage in respect of his holding or of a portion or share thereof. The period for which such a mortgage may be entered into shall not exceed seven years. If the mortgagee prevents the redemption of the mortgage or refuses to restore the land after the expiry of the period, the mortgagor may apply to the Subdivisional Magistrate for such redemption or restoration.

question: What are the rules regarding the amalgamation of holdings of a tenant in the same village?
answer: Where various parcels of land are held by one tenant within one village, and such parcels of land or some of them are the subject of separate tenancies, such parcels of land shall, under the orders of the Revenue-officer, be amalgamated into one tenancy.

question: What is Section 144 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 about?
answer: Section 144 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 deals with the revision of the record-of-rights. It empowers the Government to direct a Revenue-officer to prepare or revise a record-of-rights for a district, part of a district, or local area under certain conditions.

question: Under what conditions can the Government order the revision of a record-of-rights?
answer: The Government may order the revision of a record-of-rights if (a) not less than one-half of the total number of tenants apply for it, (b) the revision is needed to settle or avert a serious dispute among tenants, or (c) a settlement of rent is being or about to be made in the area.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVII, Section 144(2)

question: What happens when an order is made under Section 144(1)?

question: Can the Revenue-officer reassess rent under Section 144?

law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVII, Section 144(4A)

question: What are the principles to be followed in assessing rent under Section 144(4A)?

question: What happens after all appeals and objections are considered?

question: What happens to encumbrances on land included in a consolidation scheme?

question: What is the procedure for the payment of compensation for the acquisition of khas land held under wakf?

question: What are the rules regarding the payment of rent by a raiyat?
answer: A raiyat shall pay the rent in two equal instalments falling due on such dates as may be prescribed. If there is an agreement, the rent may be paid in one annual instalment falling due on the last day of the agricultural year.

question: What are the rules regarding the time and place for the payment of rent?
answer: Every raiyat shall pay or tender each instalment of rent and every non-agricultural tenant shall pay or tender the rent before sunset of the day on which it falls due. The payment may be made at the village tahsil office, at a convenient place appointed by the Collector, or by postal money-order.

If rent is sent by postal money-order, it is presumed to be tendered unless proven otherwise.

question: What are the rules regarding the redemption of a usufructuary mortgage?
answer: A usufructuary mortgage may be redeemed at any time before the expiry of the said period, on payment of an amount which shall bear the same proportion to the total consideration money received by the mortgagor, as the unexpired period bears to the total period for which the mortgage had been entered into.

question: What are the rules regarding the limitation on the mortgage of raiyat holdings?
answer: A raiyat shall not enter into any form of usufructuary mortgage other than a complete usufructuary mortgage in respect of his holding or of a portion or share thereof. The period for which such a mortgage may be entered into shall not exceed seven years.

question: What is the definition of a 'raiyat' under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'raiyat' means a person who, by virtue of section 44 or otherwise, has acquired a right to hold land directly under the Government mainly for the purpose of cultivating it by himself or by members of his family or by, or with the aid of, servants or labourers or with the aid of partners or bargadars, and includes also the successors-in-interest of persons who have acquired such a right.

question: What is the ad interim payment for a rent-receiver whose interests are acquired under section 3?

question: What is the procedure for reviewing an order under Section 150 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: Section 150 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 allows a Revenue-officer to review any order passed by himself or any of his predecessors in office. The review can be initiated either by an interested party or on the Revenue-officer's own motion. question: What is the procedure for preparing a Compensation Assessment-roll?
answer: As soon as may be after a record-of-rights in respect of any district, part of a district or local area has been prepared or revised and finally published under Chapter IV, the Revenue-officer shall prepare in the prescribed form and in the prescribed manner a Compensation Assessment-roll specifying the gross assets and the net income of all rent-receivers within such district, part or area and the compensation to be paid in accordance with the provisions of this Act to all persons whose interests are acquired under this Chapter or under Chapter II, together with such other particulars as may be prescribed.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter V, Section 33
context: The Compensation Assessment-roll is prepared after the record-of-rights is finalized and published. The roll includes details about the gross assets, net income, and compensation for those whose interests are acquired under the Act.

question: What is the procedure for certifying the final publication of a Compensation Assessment-roll?
answer: When a Compensation Assessment-roll has been finally published under section 42, the Revenue-officer shall, within such time as the Commissioner may, by general or special order require, make a certificate stating the fact of such final publication and the date thereof and shall date and subscribe the same with his name and official title.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter V, Section 43
context: The Revenue-officer must issue a certificate of final publication of the Compensation Assessment-roll within the time specified by the Commissioner. The certificate is dated and signed by the Revenue-officer.

question: How is the Compensation Assessment-roll treated for properties acquired under Chapter II?
answer: It shall not be necessary to prepare, under this Chapter, a Compensation Assessment-roll in respect of any property acquired under Chapter II, in respect of which a Compensation Assessment-roll has been prepared under Chapter VA.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter V, Section 33
context: If a Compensation Assessment-roll has already been prepared under Chapter VA for a property acquired under Chapter II, a new roll under Chapter V is not required.

question: How are proprietors, tenure-holders, and other rent-receivers treated in the Compensation Assessment-roll?
answer: In preparing such Compensation Assessment-roll every proprietor, tenure-holder or other rent-receiver collecting rents in respect of any estate, tenure, holding or tenancy or part of any estate, tenure, holding or tenancy comprised within the area to which such roll relates shall, irrespective of whether he collects such rents separately or jointly with others, be treated separately for the purpose of assessment and payment of compensation under this Chapter.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter V, Section 34
context: Each proprietor, tenure-holder, or rent-receiver is treated separately in the Compensation Assessment-roll unless they are part of a Hindu undivided family under Mitakshara law or their combined net income does not exceed five hundred rupees.

question: What is the effect of the final confirmation of a consolidation scheme on the record-of-rights?
answer: Upon the final confirmation of a scheme for consolidation of holdings under section 125, the Revenue-officer shall cause the record-of-rights, maintained under this part, to the village or villages to which such scheme relates, to be modified in accordance with the scheme as finally confirmed; and every tenant affected by such scheme shall be entitled to obtain free of cost from the Revenue-officer a copy of the record-of-rights, so modified, containing the entries as relating to him.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 126
context: The record-of-rights is modified according to the finalized consolidation scheme, and affected tenants are entitled to a free copy of the updated record.

question: When does a consolidation scheme take effect after its final confirmation?
answer: When a scheme for the consolidation of holdings has been finally confirmed under section 125, it shall take effect from the beginning of the agricultural year next after the date of the final confirmation of such scheme.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 126
context: The consolidation scheme becomes effective from the start of the agricultural year following its final confirmation.

question: What rights do individuals holding land under the Nankar, Chakran system acquire under the Act?
answer: Individuals holding land under the Nankar, Chakran system acquire a right of occupancy in all such lands so held by them, subject to the payment of a fair and equitable rent to the person under whom they hold such lands.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part III, Chapter III, Section 11

question: What is the definition of 'fair and equitable rent' in the context of the Nankar, Chakran system?
answer: Fair and equitable rent is defined as a rent not exceeding the prevailing rate of rent paid by the occupancy raiyats for lands of a similar description and with similar advantages in the same village or in the neighbouring villages, agreed upon between the tenant and his landlord, or determined by the Collector if no agreement exists.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part III, Chapter III, Section 11

question: What happens to the enactments specified in the Schedule when this Part of the Act comes into force?
answer: The enactments specified in the Schedule are repealed in that area to the extent mentioned in the fourth column of the Schedule on and from the date of coming into force of the whole of this Part in any area.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part XII, Chapter XII, Section 80

question: What is the procedure for paying compensation to outgoing rent-receivers for arrears of rent and cesses?
answer: The Government shall pay to an outgoing rent-receiver a sum equivalent to fifty per centum of such arrears (excluding interest) within four years, or alternatively, seventy per centum of the total amount actually collected by the Government out of such arrears, with the amount being deposited with the Assistant Judge for claims and awards.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IX, Section 67

question: Under what conditions can the rent payable by a raiyat or non-agricultural tenant be enhanced?
answer: The rent payable by a raiyat or non-agricultural tenant may be enhanced if it is substantially lower than the rent calculated at the rates of rent determined under the Act for similar classes of land. If the increase exceeds fifty per centum of the rent payable during the immediately preceding year, it may take effect by yearly increments.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XIV, Section 105

question: Who exercises superintendence and control over all Revenue-officers?
answer: The general superintendence and control over all Revenue-officers is vested in the Board of Land Administration.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIII, Section 146

question: What is the net income of a recusant proprietor according to the Act?
answer: The net income of a recusant proprietor is deemed to be the malikana payable to such proprietor in the agricultural year referred to in section 35, computed under section 35.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter V, Section 36

question: What are the particular details that must be recorded in the record-of-rights?
answer: The Revenue-officer shall record such particulars as may be prescribed in the record-of-rights, to be prepared or revised in pursuance of an order made under section 17.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 18

question: What is the procedure for directing persons in an area to pay rent to the Government?
answer: All persons in such area who will become tenants under the Government with effect from the first day of the agricultural year next following the publication of the notification must pay rent to the Government and not to any body else.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter V, Section 44

answer: The Government shall pay to an outgoing rent-receiver a sum equivalent to fifty per centum of such arrears (excluding interest) within four years, or alternatively, seventy per centum of the total amount actually collected by the Government out of such arrears, with the amount being deposited with the Assistant Judge for claims and awards.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IX, Section 67

question: What is Section 151A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 about?
answer: Section 151A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 provides for the exemption of rent in respect of certain land used primarily as a place of public prayer or religious worship, a public graveyard, or a public cremation ground. A malik or non-agricultural tenant can apply for rent exemption if the land is used for such purposes.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Can a tenant get rent exemption for land used as a public graveyard?
answer: Yes, a tenant can apply for rent exemption for land used as a public graveyard under Section 151A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950. The Deputy Commissioner will assess the application and determine if the land is indeed used for such purposes.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: How long does the Deputy Commissioner have to process a rent exemption application under Section 151A?
answer: The Deputy Commissioner has three months from the date of receipt of the application to process it and make a decision on whether the land is used as specified in the application.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What happens if the Deputy Commissioner is satisfied with the application under Section 151A?
answer: If the Deputy Commissioner is satisfied that the land is used as specified in the application, he will determine the area of the land so used and pass an order exempting that area from payment of rent.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Can the rent for the remaining land be reduced if a rent-free area is created under Section 151A?
answer: Yes, if a rent-free area is created under Section 151A, the Deputy Commissioner shall reduce the rent payable for the remaining holding or tenancy in proportion to the area of the rent-free tenancy.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Who can appeal against an order of the Deputy Commissioner under Section 151A?
answer: Any person aggrieved by an order of the Deputy Commissioner under Section 151A can prefer an appeal to the Commissioner of the Division within thirty days from the date of the order.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What is the time limit for appealing against an order of the Commissioner of the Division under Section 151A?
answer: Any person aggrieved by an order of the Commissioner of the Division under Section 151A can make an application to the Board of Land Administration for the revision of such order within sixty days from the date of the order.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Can the Board of Land Administration revise orders passed under Section 151A?
answer: Yes, the Board of Land Administration may, at any time, of its own motion, revise any order passed under Section 151A by the Commissioner of the Division or the Deputy Commissioner.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: When does an order for rent exemption under Section 151A take effect?
answer: An order for exemption from payment of rent under Section 151A shall take effect from the beginning of the agricultural year next after the date of such order.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What is considered a 'place of public prayer or religious worship' under Section 151A?
answer: A 'place of public prayer or religious worship' under Section 151A includes a public place specifically earmarked, permanently preserved, and regularly used exclusively for the purpose of offering prayers or worship by the followers of any particular religion or faith, such as a Mosque, Temple, Church, etc. It does not include any place used for deriving pecuniary benefit.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Who is considered a 'Deputy Commissioner' under Section 151A?
answer: Under Section 151A, 'Deputy Commissioner' includes the Additional Deputy Commissioner (Revenue).
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Can a tenant apply for rent exemption for land used as a cremation ground?
answer: Yes, a tenant can apply for rent exemption for land used as a public cremation ground under Section 151A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950. The Deputy Commissioner will assess the application and determine if the land is indeed used for such purposes.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What happens if the Deputy Commissioner is not satisfied with the application under Section 151A?
answer: If the Deputy Commissioner is not satisfied with the application under Section 151A, he shall pass an order rejecting the application.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Can the Deputy Commissioner create a separate rent-free tenancy under Section 151A?
answer: Yes, if the area determined under Section 151A forms a part of a holding or tenancy, the Deputy Commissioner shall separate such area from the rest of the holding or tenancy and create a separate rent-free tenancy for such area.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What is the meaning of 'public graveyard' under Section 151A?
answer: Under Section 151A, a 'public graveyard' refers to a place primarily used for the burial of the deceased and is considered as land used for public purposes.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Is there any exception for places used for pecuniary benefit under Section 151A?
answer: Yes, under Section 151A, any place used for deriving pecuniary benefit is excluded from the definition of 'place of public prayer or religious worship'.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What is the procedure for the revision of the Commissioner of the Division's order under Section 151A?
answer: Any person aggrieved by an order of the Commissioner of the Division under Section 151A may, within sixty days from the date of such order, make an application to the Board of Land Administration for the revision of such order.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What happens to the rent after the creation of a separate rent-free tenancy under Section 151A?
answer: After the creation of a separate rent-free tenancy under Section 151A, the remaining part of the holding or tenancy will continue to be subject to rent, while the rent-free area is excluded.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: Can a tenant apply for rent exemption for land used for public purposes under Section 151A?
answer: Yes, a tenant can apply for rent exemption for land used for public purposes such as public prayer, cremation, or graveyard under Section 151A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What is the procedure for the Deputy Commissioner to determine the rent-free area under Section 151A?
answer: Under Section 151A, the Deputy Commissioner will determine the rent-free area by separating it from the rest of the holding or tenancy and creating a separate rent-free tenancy for such area.

question: Can the Deputy Commissioner reject an application under Section 151A?

law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151A

question: What is the significance of the agricultural year under Section 151A?

question: What is the procedure for the tenant to apply for rent exemption under Section 151A?
answer: A tenant can apply for rent exemption under Section 151A by submitting an application to the Deputy Commissioner, who will then assess the application and determine if the land is used for public purposes such as prayer, cremation, or graveyard.

question: What is the process for consolidation of holdings and handling objections?
answer: When a scheme for consolidation of holdings has been prepared, the Revenue-officer shall cause a draft of the scheme to be published in the prescribed manner and for the prescribed period. During this period, any objections made regarding entries or omissions in the scheme are received and considered. The Revenue-officer then disposes of such objections according to rules made by the Government. If no objections are made or if they are resolved, the Revenue-officer passes an order confirming the scheme with or without modifications.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 123

question: What are the rights of a rent-receiver regarding ad interim payments?
answer: A rent-receiver whose interests are acquired under sub-section (1) of section 3 is entitled to receive an ad interim payment annually at one-third of the net income for the year. For khas land acquired under sub-section (2) of section 3, the rent-receiver is entitled to an ad interim payment at five percent of the compensation payable for the land. The net income is calculated by deducting specific items from the gross collections, including previous annual payments, taxes, maintenance costs, and collection charges.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 123

question: What is the procedure for removing a tenant's homestead if it is within the landlord's homestead?
answer: A tenant or landlord may apply to the Civil Court for an order to remove the tenant's homestead within six months of the Act's commencement. The Court, after hearing both parties and considering evidence, may direct the removal if the tenant's land is within the landlord's homestead. If the tenant's total cultivable land is less than five standard bighas, the Court may assess compensation for removal, reconstruction, and land costs. The landlord must deposit the assessed compensation or the tenant must admit receipt before an order is made.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part III, Chapter III, Section 12

question: How is the net income of a recusant proprietor calculated?
answer: The net income of a recusant proprietor of a temporarily settled private estate is deemed to be the amount payable to such a proprietor in the agricultural year, as computed under section 35. This is the malikana payable in the agricultural year referred to in sub-clause (i) or (ii) of clause (a) of sub-section (1) of section 35.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter V, Section 36

question: What is the procedure for handling objections during the publication of a consolidation scheme?
answer: When a consolidation scheme is prepared, the Revenue-officer publishes a draft of the scheme in the prescribed manner and for the prescribed period. During this period, any objections made regarding entries or omissions in the scheme are received and considered. The Revenue-officer disposes of such objections according to rules made by the Government. If no objections are made or if they are resolved, the Revenue-officer passes an order confirming the scheme with or without modifications.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 123

question: What are the provisions for ad interim payments to rent-receivers in cases of khas land acquisition?
answer: A rent-receiver whose khas land is acquired under sub-section (2) of section 3 is entitled to receive an ad interim payment annually at five percent of the amount of compensation payable for such land under sub-section (1) of section 39. The provisions of sub-sections (2), (3), and (4) of section 39 apply mutatis mutandis in determining the amount of compensation.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter V, Section 6

question: What is the procedure for ad interim payments to rent-receivers in cases of temporary settled private estates?
answer: A rent-receiver whose interests are acquired under sub-section (1) of section 3 is entitled to receive an ad interim payment annually at one-third of the net income for the year. The net income is computed by deducting specific items from the gross collections, including previous annual payments, taxes, maintenance costs, and collection charges. The Revenue-officer is guided by rules made by the Government in determining the amounts of deductions.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter V, Section 6

question: What are the provisions for ad interim payments in cases of wakf or other trust lands?
answer: Nothing in this section applies to any estate, taluk, tenure, holding, tenancy, or land held under wakf, wakf-al-al-aulad, debutter, or any other trust. Thus, these lands are excluded from the ad interim payment provisions.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter V, Section 6

question: What is the procedure for the removal of a tenant's homestead if the tenant's land is less than five standard bighas?
answer: If the tenant's total cultivable land, besides the homestead in question, is less than five standard bighas, the Court may assess reasonable compensation for the removal and reconstruction of the homestead. The landlord must deposit the assessed compensation with the Court or the tenant must admit receipt in writing before an order for removal is made.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part III, Chapter III, Section 12

question: What is the procedure for ad interim payments if the rent-receiver is not paid under sub-section (1) of section 6?
answer: The Government may pay to any such rent-receiver a sum in lieu of ad interim payment, calculated at one-sixth of the net income of such interest determined under section 35 or 36, in the Compensation Assessment-roll finally published under section 42, subject to modification under section 54, for each year of which ad interim payment is due but not paid.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter V, Section 6

question: What happens if land exempted from rent under Section 151A is no longer used for its intended purpose?
answer: If land exempted from rent under Section 151A is no longer used for the purpose for which the exemption was granted, it becomes liable to be re-assessed for rent. The Deputy Commissioner has the authority to re-assess the rent at a fair and equitable rate, based on similar lands in the same or neighboring villages.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIA, Section 151B

question: What is the procedure for re-assessing rent under Section 151B?
answer: The Deputy Commissioner may re-assess the rent of land that has ceased to be used for its exempted purpose. Before doing so, they must give at least fifteen days' notice to the affected persons, allowing them to appear and be heard in the matter.

question: What is the restriction on alienation of land by aboriginals under the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?

The interest and proceeds are paid to the rightful heirs or beneficiaries, and if no such person exists, the proceeds are reinvested in Government securities.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter VIII, Section 59
context: This section provides the framework for the management of compensation paid to individuals who were not legally entitled to alienate property, including the investment and distribution of funds.

question: What is the purpose of Section 151D of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: Section 151D of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 requires heads of families who hold more than twenty-five bighas of agricultural land to submit a statement to the Revenue Officer by January 31, 1973. This is to provide a record of their land holdings for administrative purposes.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIB, Section 151D

question: Who is required to submit the statement under Section 151D?
answer: Heads of families who, individually or collectively with their family members, hold more than twenty-five standard bighas of agricultural land in Bangladesh on December 16, 1971, or on the date of submission of the statement.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XVIIIB, Section 151D

question: What is the deadline for submitting the statement under Section 151D?
answer: The deadline for submitting the statement is January 31, 1973. However, the Government may extend this deadline for all cases, specific cases, or specific areas as it deems fit.

question: What is the consequence of not submitting the required statement under Section 151D?
answer: The law does not explicitly mention penalties for non-submission, but failure to comply may result in administrative actions or legal consequences as determined by the Revenue Officer or the Government.

question: What is the procedure for the sale of a holding or tenancy for arrears of rent?
answer: The holding of a raiyat or the tenancy of a non-agricultural tenant shall be liable to sale in execution of a certificate signed under the Bengal Public Demands Recovery Act, 1913, for the rent thereof, and the rent shall be a first charge thereon.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter XVI, Section 139
context: The holding or tenancy is liable to sale for arrears of rent under the Bengal Public Demands Recovery Act, 1913. The rent is considered a first charge on the holding or tenancy.

question: What are the rules for the apportionment of land-revenue and cesses when a share of an estate is acquired by the Government?
answer: When the interests of a rent-receiver or rent-receivers in a share or part of any estate have been acquired by the Government, the land-revenue and cesses payable for the parent estate shall be apportioned between the acquired share or part and the remaining share or part according to specific principles based on separate accounts, proportion of shares, or area of land.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter XI, Section 76A
context: Section 76A outlines the apportionment of land-revenue and cesses when a share of an estate is acquired by the Government. The apportionment is based on whether the acquired share has a separate account, a proportion of the share, or a specific portion of land.

question: How is the rent of a tenure, holding, or tenancy apportioned when a portion is acquired under the Act?
answer: When the interests in a portion of a tenure, holding, or other tenancy have been acquired under this Act and such portion consists of a definite share, the rent shall be apportioned between the acquired and unacquired portions according to such share. If it does not consist of a definite share, the Revenue-officer may apportion the rent on the basis of area or value as may appear fair and equitable.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter XI, Section 76A
context: Section 76A specifies that the rent of a tenure, holding, or tenancy is apportioned between the acquired and unacquired portions either according to a definite share or on the basis of area or value, as determined by the Revenue-officer.

question: What is the procedure for preparing a Compensation Assessment-roll in special cases involving properties acquired under Chapter II?
answer: The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, order that a Compensation Assessment-roll be prepared in respect of the properties of any rent-receiver acquired under section 3, based on returns, papers, and documents furnished or taken possession of under sections 3A and 4. The Revenue-officer shall verify, correct, and settle fair and equitable rents, and prepare the Compensation Assessment-roll in the prescribed form.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter VA, Section 46A
context: Section 46A outlines the procedure for preparing a Compensation Assessment-roll in special cases involving properties acquired under Chapter II. It includes verifying documents, settling rents, and preparing the roll in the prescribed form.

question: What are the rules for the creation of a separate estate and apportionment of revenue when a share of an estate is acquired?
answer: When the interests of a rent-receiver or rent-receivers in a share or part of any estate have been acquired by the Government, the remaining share or part of such estate shall be deemed to constitute a separate estate. The land-revenue and cesses payable for the parent estate shall be apportioned between the acquired share or part and the separate estate according to specific principles based on separate accounts, proportion of shares, or area of land.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter XI, Section 76A
context: Section 76A outlines the creation of a separate estate and the apportionment of revenue when a share of an estate is acquired by the Government. The apportionment is based on the principles of separate accounts, proportion of shares, or area of land.

question: What is the procedure for correcting the Compensation Assessment-roll?
answer: The Revenue-officer shall make such alterations in the records-of-rights or the Compensation Assessment-roll as may be necessary to give effect to any directions issued by the Commissioner or other officer under section 49 or an order made by a Special Judge under section 51 or section 53 or under sub-section (4) of section 52 or to any final order or decree of a Civil Court or High Court passed in any suit, appeal or proceeding declaring title to and, or possession of any land.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter VII, Section 54
context: Section 54 outlines the procedure for correcting the Compensation Assessment-roll. The Revenue-officer must make necessary alterations based on directions from the Commissioner, orders from a Special Judge, or final orders from a Civil Court or High Court.

question: What is the procedure for serving notice to a rent-receiver for furnishing a return before notification?
answer: Under Section 3A, the Revenue-officer may serve a notice on a rent-receiver directing him to furnish a return within sixty days, showing details such as total area, revenue, land in khas possession, co-sharers, and other necessary information.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part II, Chapter II, Section 3A
context: The notice must be served in the prescribed manner, and the return must include details of estates, taluks, tenures, land in khas possession, co-sharers, and other necessary information.

question: What happens to ad interim payments once a compensation assessment is finalized?
answer: Ad interim payments cease upon the publication of a notification. The total amount of ad interim payments is deducted from the compensation amount, with a 3% annual interest calculated from the date the payments became payable until the last day of the agricultural year in which the notification was published.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 28
context: Section 28 of the Act specifies that ad interim payments are deducted from the compensation amount after the notification is published, with interest calculated at 3% per annum.

question: What is the procedure for the consolidation of holdings under the Act?
answer: Any two or more raiyats with lands in the same or contiguous villages may apply to the Revenue-officer for consolidation. If not less than two-thirds of the raiyats in a village or block of villages, holding at least three-fourths of the total cultivable area, apply for consolidation, the application is deemed to be on behalf of all raiyats in the area.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 119
context: Section 119 outlines that applications for consolidation of holdings can be made by two or more raiyats, and if a majority of the raiyats in a village or block apply, the application is considered on behalf of all.

question: What are the rights of a raiyat regarding the use of land in his holding?
answer: A raiyat has the right to occupy and use the land in his holding in any manner he likes, subject to the provisions of the Act.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XIII, Section 83
context: Section 83 grants raiyats the right to use their land in their holding as they see fit, provided it is within the legal framework of the Act.

question: How are fair and equitable rents determined for non-agricultural tenants?
answer: The Revenue-officer determines the fair and equitable rent for non-agricultural tenants based on the provisions of Section 23. If the existing rent exceeds the fair and equitable rent by more than fifty percent, the Revenue-officer fixes the rent at a rate not exceeding fifty percent above the fair and equitable rate.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 25
context: Section 25 outlines the process for determining fair and equitable rents for non-agricultural tenants, including the presumption of existing rent being fair unless it exceeds the fair rate by more than fifty percent.

question: What is the procedure for creating separate holdings or tenancies for a portion of a holding?
answer: Where a rent-receiver holds only a portion of a holding or tenancy in his khas possession, such a portion is constituted into a separate holding or tenancy and assessed to rent separately. The Revenue-officer considers the original rent, proportionate area, and value of the new holding or tenancy.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 27
context: Section 27 of the Act specifies that a portion of a holding or tenancy held by a rent-receiver in khas possession is made into a separate holding or tenancy and assessed to rent separately.

question: What is the process for confirming a scheme for the consolidation of holdings?
answer: When a consolidation scheme is submitted along with an application, and it is agreed to by all affected raiyats, the Revenue-officer examines the scheme and may confirm it with or without modification. However, the scheme cannot be confirmed if the total rent of all holdings under the scheme is reduced due to redistribution of lands.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XV, Section 121
context: Section 121 outlines that a consolidation scheme can be confirmed by the Revenue-officer if it is agreed upon by all affected raiyats, but the scheme cannot be confirmed if it results in a reduction of total rent.

question: What are the effects of rents settled under the preparation of record-of-rights?
answer: All rents determined under the preparation of record-of-rights and entered in the record-of-rights finally published under section 19 are deemed to be correctly determined and fair and equitable for the purposes of the Act. No suit can be brought in a Civil Court regarding the determination of such rents.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 29
context: Section 29 states that rents determined under the preparation of record-of-rights are deemed fair and equitable, and no Civil Court can entertain suits related to their determination.

question: What is the procedure for the acquisition of the interests of certain rent-receivers?

question: What is the procedure for the preparation of the record-of-rights?
answer: The Revenue-officer prepares or revises the record-of-rights under the Act, determining fair and equitable rents for non-agricultural tenants in accordance with the provisions of Section 23. The record-of-rights is published and deemed to be correctly determined.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part IV, Chapter IV, Section 25

question: What happens if someone who is exempt from land revenue acquires more than 25 standard bigahs of agricultural land?

question: When does the liability to pay land revenue start for someone who acquires agricultural land?
answer: The liability to pay land revenue starts from the first day of Kartik of the Bengali year if the acquisition was before that date. question: What is the limit on the transfer of land for a raiyat?
answer: The holding of a raiyat or a share or portion thereof shall not be transferred, except to a bona fide cultivator, and no such transfer shall be valid if the area of land held by the transferee exceeds three hundred and seventy-five standard bighas.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XIII, Section 90

question: How is compensation determined for the acquisition of interests in temporary tenancies?
answer: Compensation for the acquisition of interests in temporary tenancies is paid out of the compensation payable to the immediately superior landlord, and the Revenue-officer apportions the compensation between the tenant and the landlord, taking into account the unexpired period of the tenancy.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XIII, Section 90

question: What is the procedure for the Land Survey Tribunal in handling disputes?
answer: The Land Survey Tribunal follows the procedure under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, for the disposal of suits or appeals, and has powers such as summoning witnesses, requiring documents, and issuing commissions for examinations.

question: What is the compensation for the acquisition of interests in wakf properties?
answer: The compensation for wakf properties dedicated to charitable or religious purposes is assessed as a perpetual annuity equal to the net income or portion of the net income dedicated to such purposes.
law_reference: State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950, Part V, Chapter XIII, Section 90

question: What are the limitations on the purchase or acquisition of land by non-cultivators?
